/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Let's move to https://review.opendev.org/c/opendev/system-config/+/817136 where we have some discussion already going!
Hi Rodolfo, code-wise this looks good but the failures in the unittests looks related to this change
Yeah, I didn't have time to check this patch. Let me take a look.

Thanks Rodolfo.
Is there any impact at scale in terms of performance when breaking things into multiple individual transactions?

I understand that the patch minimizes/solves the issue described in the linked bug but I want to make sure of the point above. If the performance impact is significant, can't we assume that the Neutron API is fenced during the migration and keep the single-txn approach?

We can't guarantee the process DB isolation while processing each resource individually.

And yes, this approach will take more time than with one single txn.

Let me propose another alternative.

I thought this could be fixed just by calling the DB modifications before starting the DB sync script https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/ac245b3b5bc1512361fc938da8670759a9719497/neutron/cmd/ovn/neutron_ovn_db_sync_util.py#L247

It even makes more sense to modify the DB and then sync it to the OVN. Does anybody see any drawbacks in doing as such?
Looks ok for me but I think that Kuba's questions should be answered before we will move on with that one.

This patch should prevent any DB concurrency problem we had before. But it doesn't matter when, during the migration process, the DB migration is done. We could have other concurrent operations at any point because this is a live system.

Moving the DB migration before the OVN sync will not prevent the "ml2_port_bindings" stale data error we saw in our tests.
So with that approach, just changing the order we would avoid having to have separate transactions as this patch suggests ?

FWIW I agree with Kuba but can't see if there's any other drawbacks. For example, what if the sync script fails? Then a snapshot of the db should be restored right?
This is ok but should be probably documented.

roles/stage-output/tasks/main.yaml.message:
Because it is not handled here anymore (line 72).  As I wrote in the commit message " Move the handling of those files/directories to its own place later, after copying all files to logs/."
It is pointless to fix the names for just part of the files (the files specified directly under zuul_copy_output, thus excluding files inside directories specified under zuul_copy_output) and then check again for files starting with "." on all copied files.

This is exactly the reason for this change. Right now, given this input:
zuul_copy_output:
   '.myfile': logs
   'mydir': log

.myfile is renamed as _.myfile, but the dot files under mydir are not renamed.
Why is this dropped in this change?
Because it's not needed. Both the source path and the destination path are absolute paths.
Since you're regex_replace'ing it wouldn't be trailing right? (ie it'd be at the beginning)
This doesn't handle folders as such?  The find below is only for files.  I don't know what would happen with a .directory (like a config dir I guess) ... is it something we need to handle?

But previously top level dirs were renamed. eg: `.dir1/.dir2/file` would become `_dir1/.dir2/file` right? So while it's difficult to do recursively as you've mentioned this is still a regression and we should probably look to handle the top level case.

Maybe, but there is no easy solution. Renaming the directories means that we could hit this:
foo/.dir1/.dir2

and the rename should be done first on the leaves, which would makes coding this in ansible more complicated and probably out of scope. Maybe a python module could help.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Thanks Julia! Interesting ideas. I don't recall hearing of a desire for this at Yahoo. Which doesn't mean there isn't, I may not know of it. When the ironic nodes are active, we don't know what the tenants are using those nodes for -- i would think it would be up to them to decide to reduce power or not... (and my guess is that this might not be a high priority for them). I think there might be cases (as Arne mentioned) when ironic nodes are not in active, when we might want to crank down the power, or power off (if we don't already). eg, nodes in some error state could be powered off, then powered on when/if someone decides to look into the error. (Or maybe powered off after x amount of time if no one has looked at it?? dunno.)

Thanks, Julia! I like the overall idea to add means to Ironic to help with power savings.

From what I understand from the spec, there would be an additional state for active nodes
in which power saving BIOS settings are applied out-of-band, i.e. via Redfish. Is that a correct summary?

What about nodes in fast-track which are in available, i.e. powered on but not yet in active?
Equally, nodes in error or other state may also profit from such a mechanism: why run at full speed if they are broken at the moment?

This is why I was thinking if an additional state is not too heavy/inflexible for this and rather have
these nodes tagged, along with some task to adapt the power saving settings?

As an alternative/additional (maybe crazy) idea: how about a mechanism which allows Ironic to switch off active nodes and check them at regular intervals, e.g. switch them on? This could potentially save a lot more power.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I guess, my thought on why focus on a workflow driven approach is because most of these things are *really* going to require a power cycle.

I man, we *can* and *should* likely include one of the cpu power tuning daemons in IPA images so machines can idle CPU cores while not in use. I guess ultimately, no matter what, we need to kind of map out what the best operational gains would be for operators, and balance that with our sanity.

Powered off after x time is likely a great addition. No sense to leave things on forever if they are broken... as long as it is *not* a cleanfail.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
So in essence, that is a good summary.

I hadn't thought about nodes in fast track, and truthfully there are a ton of different use cases and patterns, so I think it might be good. There is one conundrum, many of the settings which impact power utilization also change cpu/memory geometry and behavior of a system.

My primary case I kind of want to support is backup and tertiary redundant systems like those in use in telecom environments where systems need to be on, but may only take traffic if some sort of disaster occurs, in which case some time to spin up the systems seems acceptable, at least to me. One of the operational requirements that I've heard from a few places is they need to keep the machines on, to ensure issues are identified, as opposed to off where they can't actively be aware of the state and remedy issues in advance.

I guess, in other words, nobody wants to go over to the disaster systems and find out they are broken too.

I do think some sort of mechanism does may sense like a "usage poller" or whatnot, but I also think that is going to vary. Like in Nobodycam's case, I suspect it may be semi-manual or human engaged for some of his infrastructure, where as for a infra operator, maybe good to shut them down, where as others, maybe they need to apply logic to take them to low power mode. I *suspect* some of that interaction can't really be Ironic driven, and maybe something like watcher is better.

specs/backlog/power-management.rst.message: Does this imply we need to model PDUs and their relationship to chassis and nodes? This would feed into my suggestion below.

How about extending the chassis and allocation model so that is possible to implement these sorts of scheduling policies:
- pack one chassis/PDU completely before activating another
- modelling the physical relationship of chassis within the data warehouse, so that activated chassis are evenly distributed within the space to avoid overworking the cooling in one area (or packed together in one cooling domain so others can be put in standby)

Maybe these policies would require the allocation API to be backed by the placement service to be feasible?

swift/container/backend.py.message: I lifted this from https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/809317 and TBH I'm not yet sure what the significance of the reconciler_sync_point is - perhaps someone can suggest a comment to help understanding?

My understanding is that the trouble is something like this:

Shards get created on the wrong side of a split-brain, so they have the wrong policy. But they all *agree* on the wrong policy, so they all slurp up a bunch of rows and work to ensure those objects are in the wrong policy, and all replicas get their reconciler_sync_point close to MAX_ROW.

With Matt's patch, the *root* can now come along and push the shards over to the *right* policy. In the unsharded case, we'd rely on the one replica that had the right policy receiving all the bad rows from the other replicas and enqueuing a bunch of reconciler work. With this externally-driven change, nobody will look at the old rows unless we reset the sync point.

Makes me worry that we might have a lurking bug today on master if the one guy that knows about the right policy winds up receiving an rsync-then-merge... I think we might get the rsynced rows and reconciler_sync_point, but the corrected policy index -- which could mean some rows that are never considered for reconciler work.

(Now I kind of want a container watcher that tallies up misplaced objects since the sync point and compares against the totals in the policy_stat table. If they don't match, log about it -- and maybe, optionally, go ahead and reset the sync point?)

All that said, it sucks that the reset will kick off a full table scan to look for reconciler work on the next replication cycle. Makes me glad we've already got the `WHERE storage_policy_index <> ?` below!

do we really want the status_changed_at to go backwards?

the sync_point resets the rows to be evaluated by the _post_replicate_hook so dump_to_reconciler can re-evaluate all the rows given the new correct policy index - i don't really understand yet why it ever worked?

Clay we need to go backwards otherwise we can't pull in the root's status_changed_at time which will make the SPI checks fail in known bad cases. In fact it's what I had to do to get your follow up of  https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/809317 to actaully work. Really it's just a shame we call it last_modified_at and not something like last_state_change to indicate when we last PUT or DELETEd the container.

Or maybe we loose it all together and just just having a virtual property in the broker that is:

  @property
  last_state_change_at(self):
     info = self.get_info()
     return max(info['put_timestamp'], info['delete_timestamp']

So who is responsible for bumping status_changed_at now? When do they do it?

status_changed_at is set:

1) when the container db is created (==put_timestamp)
2) when the container is re-created (==put_timestamp)
3) when the container is deleted (==delete_timestamp)

during replication:
4) if incorrect_policy_index then during set_storage_policy_index
5) during merge_timestamps, if delete status changes, then set to 'now' (and this happens after 4 so could override 4!?!)

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
It would be good to emphasis this is a workaround, not an actual fix.

The fix is:
- add support for "type" in the docker_config.volume
- add the /dev/pts mount as "devpts" type when we bind-mount /dev in the container

ack waiting on the test 
(sorry i updated the depends on so just did a recheck @ https://review.rdoproject.org/r/c/testproject/+/34926/10#message-d3baee5e121c938157b93ab9104cc8734b72335d )

I think the proper fix should be done in tripleo, and not CI-only. Please reach out the HW provisioning and Storage teams to fix the iscsi and ironic_conductor containers that bind mount /dev to stop doing so.

Note:
it's not only /dev/pts/ptmx issue, especially when we mount /dev in containers.

in an actual container, /dev/ptmx is indeed a symlink to /dev/pts/ptmx (with container_file_t context, and 0666 mode).
But on the host, /dev/ptmx is its own thing, and has its own SELinux label, different from the one in /dev/pts/ptmx.

incidently, container_t is NOT allowed to access the context of /dev/ptmx, while it's allowed on /dev/pts/ptmx.

So I'm not really sure the issue is the rights on /dev/pts/ptmx - in addition, since we're mounting /dev in the container, the change will affect the host itself.... We do NOT want this outside of CI, and even in CI, it should be a temporary workaround. I'm trying to get some more data around this issue, and it seems we MIGHT be able to drop some of the /dev bind-mounts, but clearly not all of them. Maybe a new policy will be needed in the end...

Solutions will involve, among things:
- stop mounting the whole /dev in containers (where possible)
- potentially some hacking in container context in order to make them "unique" (i.e. not using container_file_t), allowing us to get a targeted SELinux policy allowing access to the /dev/ptmx
- a lot of aspirin and other painkillers for the coming headaches.

Sorry for the long comment ;).

tests/unit/test_configloader.py.message:
Thinking about this a little bit more....

I wrote https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/816767 to implement my suggestion.  I think we should probably land that, but technically I don't think it's strictly necessary.

What I think we should do is:

1) Instantiate all of the drivers and connections in zuul-web (we only instantiate the ones with webhooks now).  That's because I think no matter what the configloader is going to need the full set of connections and their connection branch caches.

2) Alter the onLoad method to be aware of whether it's being used in a scheduler or web context.  Right now, GerritConnection.onLoad instantiates the branch cache (good for both) as well as starts the background ssh stream thread (bad for web).

3) Base this all on 816767 so that the connections on zuul-web don't have to make any outbound calls to get branches.  Maybe also update the getProjectBranches method to fail if it is running in zuul-web and it doesn't have the branch list cached.

This is going to conflict with the project branch cache stack which is about to merge.  But it should be an easy fix.  We'll just need to supply branch cache min_ltimes to loadTenant.

I think we probably don't ever want a zuul-web loading a tenant without a layout state.  Obviously this is a test method, but we might want to think about testing that here?

Since we'll have a layout state, we can use those min_ltimes for the caches.

Finally, this makes me think that we may want to go ahead and make sure that the branch cache is always populated.  Currently we sometimes clear parts of the cache and expect the scheduler+connection to query and fill in the missing data.  But zuul-web instances won't have connections to do that with, so we need to rely entirely on ZK.  If a scheduler clears an entry from the branch cache while zuul-web is trying to read from it, we'll error.

Regarding 2): The onLoad() method is only called in registerScheduler() which we don't call in zuul-web. So we should be safe here. But if I understand you correctly, we would need parts of onLoad() in zuul-web as well to initialize the branch cache.

Maybe it would work if we call onLoad() directly in zuul-web (not via registerScheduler) and add a check inside the onLoad() method that checks if self.sched is set. In case it's not set we could skip the steps that aren't necessary (or even bad).

Thanks for the comments. I will have a look at those.
But I think those suggestions should be implemented in https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/816361/3, or? There I add the ConfigLoader and other parts to zuul-web. 

I think 1) is already implemented as otherwise I wasn't able to use the ConfigLoader in zuul-web because of missing connections. That's why I changed e.g. https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/816361/3/zuul/cmd/web.py#91.

I've addressed 2) and 3) in a dedicated change https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/816807. I've based that change directly on master as it's mostly independent. We can rebase this change here later on when the rest of the branch cache stack is merged.

I don't think so, the only reason i can think to why you might want separate server and client certs is to reduce the risk if one of the certificates was compromised, but if that happens I think you have a bigger problem.
can we install the client/server certs/keys for libvirt and qemu once and have them both reference the same path? Doubling the number of install tasks for each compute node is a fair overhead?

Is it possible to configure either of libvirt or qemu to look at an alternative certificate path, through the config file? That would avoid needing to do any symlinking. This may of course be an unnecessary optimisation.

I did think about this, but then wasn't sure where that could be neatly added, as the PKI role just supports copy, not symlinks.

Let's reduce complexity where possible imo.

It is possible to configure libvirt's server cert file path, but not the client cert file path
https://libvirt.org/remote.html#Remote_libvirtd_configuration

For QEMU it possible to set the directory but not the filename and unhelpfully libvirt uses `servercert.pem` and qemu `server-cert.pem`
https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/blob/8970094afd473234a3cbf0d8f1f8cbe6e2e421b7/src/qemu/qemu.conf#L25

So to reduce the number of copy operations we could set libvirt to use the server cert and CA in /etc/pki/qemu/
But libvirt would still used the client cert in /etc/pki/libvirt/
This would remove 3 copies per compute host.

Do you think this is worth the increased complexity?
Or we could add symlinks?

cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py.message:
This patch should only fix this specific issue, but after reading your bug report I think we should also fix (in a different patch) ALL similar issues related to it, since at least the following operations on encrypted resources:

- Create bigger volume from snapshot
- Clone volume to bigger volume
- Extend volume

Result in volumes with less available space than requested, since the encryption overhead will take up part of the available volume space instead of having a slightly larger volume in RBD so the user can have the exact size that was requested.

Do you know if we have a bug for these cases?

Yes, this must be done!
This patch is just avoiding a known problem(not fix the root).

Create bigger volume from snapshot -> No error.
Clone volume to bigger volume      -> No error.
Extend volume                      -> No error.
Create a bigger volume and extend volume works fine in my test env. I think no problem is reasonable, because they only increase the space (provided that luks does not take up more than 1024M space).

When I mentioned issues I didn't mean that they would fail or return an error, but they just have less space than they should, because there's a part used by the encryption metadata.  We need to find a way to make this consistent across all backends so that we can migrate without problem.
Does this really only affect encrypted volumes?  What happened before this change with non-encrypted volumes?

I just used _extend_if_required in patch 1, but size for snapshot is snapshot.volume_size, not snapshot.size.
 o(╥﹏╥)o

I think the problem only happens with encrypted volumes, because it actually shrinks the volumes.

For non-encrypted volumes all that probably happens is that me make an unnecessary call.

By the way, we have the equivalent check in _extend_if_required which is used by create_cloned_volume

No, it will affect all volumes that created from snapshot.
Before this change, all volume will do resize even the size is just the same.

Yes, you are right, we don't have show_log policy. But we have api mentioned here - https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/index.html?show-log&expanded=show-log-detail.

I think we need to add show_log policy in neutron

While going through the other neutron policies and patrole tests, I found that there is no implementation of show rule, in fact in neutron AFAIK, create, delete, update and get operations have been implemented for all the policies. Hence, the show operation for the respective extension have been implemented using get rule in Patrole.

Hence, I am correcting the show_log policy here with the get_log rule.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: For reference, the endpoint used for consulting the kube-apiserver health status is as suggested on the official docs: https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/health-checks/

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message:
I dont know if it really matters but according to the health check page
after you check for readyz, you should verify that the return code is 200.

-k means insecure.  I expect that is intentional and required here so maybe we should also add a comment to indicate why it is needed.
Done

curl return code is different than 0 when the request fails, what happens during the kube-apiserver restart:

```
controller-0:~$ sudo /usr/bin/kill -s SIGHUP $(pidof kube-apiserver)
controller-0:~$ curl -k https://localhost:6443/readyz
curl: (7) Failed connect to localhost:6443; Connection refused
controller-0:~$ echo $?
7
```

This is enough for puppet to retry it N times as defined here.

Regarding the -k, yes, it is intentional because k8s doesn't seem provide a valid certificate on these endpoints, given they are somehow 'internal':

```
controller-0:~$ curl https://localhost:6443/readyz
curl: (60) Peer's Certificate issuer is not recognized.
More details here: http://curl.haxx.se/docs/sslcerts.html

curl performs SSL certificate verification by default, using a "bundle"
 of Certificate Authority (CA) public keys (CA certs). If the default
 bundle file isn't adequate, you can specify an alternate file
 using the --cacert option.
If this HTTPS server uses a certificate signed by a CA represented in
 the bundle, the certificate verification probably failed due to a
 problem with the certificate (it might be expired, or the name might
 not match the domain name in the URL).
If you'd like to turn off curl's verification of the certificate, use
 the -k (or --insecure) option.
controller-0:~$ echo $?
60
controller-0:~$ curl -k https://localhost:6443/readyz
okcontroller-0:~echo $?
0
```

I've added a comment pointing to the docs, thanks for the suggestion!
similar comment as before.  if we do need to check the http code.
Done
It might be okay to increase the waiting period to 5s instead. I'm not sure about this service, but too frequent request cause a http flood
I don't think it's necessary to keep polling so often. This root-ca update procedure is supposed to be rare so it's probably fine for the user to wait 4 seconds longer.
Also added a 10s timeout for each try to avoid a longer hanging in case the endpoint isn't responding.
Done

The curl timeout doesn't have much of an impact here because during the transient, when kube-apiserver is still not up most of the requests are rejected instantly on the endpoint, and this timeout only takes place in a minimal timeframe where kube-apiserver is up but cannot yet respond to requests. So, in the failure path where kube-apiserver doesn't come back, the timeout of this step is very close to what we are setting and expecting here: 90 seconds.

I've increased the try_sleep to 5 hoping that this addresses your concerns.

Rafael, how long did you have to wait for the update to fail in the failure path test? curl does have timeout mechanism. But looks like we need to characterize the default timeout then we can decide what could be a proper interval between curl retries.
We also want to know how long it takes for the update to fail in case apiserver never comes back. The update should fail in a reasonable time if apiserver never comes back.

Some considerations here:
  - This endpoint is specialized in providing only metrics about the health status of k8s, which can be consulted at any time by different sources
  - curl already have an internal wait/timeout system
  - Bigger sleep here means a longer hanging on the update command for the user

Based on that I think it's fair to assume that the endpoint is built to handle
this amount of requests but I've also just tested stressing it with a large
amount of requests without sleep both with kube-apiserver up and down and had no
issues so based on that I think we should keep the 1s sleep.

Just realized that these block needs to move to after line 927, so it is chained with apiserver restart. Otherwise it could be executed before apiserver restart. ('update_kubelet_conf' and 'restart_kubelet' chain can be executed in parallel with the apiserver restart chain)
Done
Good catch Andy, fixed.

As discussed in PTG, we can rename the existing SIG 'Extended Maintenance' to handle it, which is nothing but the same person Elod who takes care of stable policy + EM team.

- https://governance.openstack.org/sigs/

And project team can manage the stable cores in their project stable core team as they do for the core team.

Yeah, a contact list for stable things. I agree we need more people there, and like API SIG, we can keep this SIG (renaming or so) as a place if any more members want to join as an advisory group instead of the expectation of doing all the stable work which is current structure.

Well, Stable Support Team became Extended Maintenance SIG in the past, so for sure, we can rename it Stable SIG or something like that to better represent that it supports the stable releases in general, not just the extended maintenance process and those releases.

Though the real problem is really that there are not that many active stable maintainer. I really feel that the original problem with "stable policy has to change, because it is hard to maintain old and every stable branches" came from this very same problem: if the stable branches are not actively maintained, then when someone has to touch them, it is painful to fix every single issue that has grown in the meantime.

To be a stable core for a team is really just to understand and follow the 'stable policy'. Maybe every team should try to involve a reasonably part of its active cores into their stable maintenance. We should somehow encourage this. On the other hand, we won't solve the issue for those teams where there are lack of active cores for the master branch as well.
I don't see how creating (or renaming) a SIG "solves" anything mentioned above. This is really just a contact list of who to ask about stable things?

I think this is the only proposed change, the stuff below seems like filler.

I *think* what you're saying here is "some projects don't have stable teams and because 'extended maintenance' doesn't have the word 'stable' in it, they're completely at a loss for who to ask about stable things." (sarcasm is my own) Is that right? If so, I think maybe adding some words like that (sans sarcasm) might be helpful to understand what you're going for.

If the above isn't correct, then I don't understand the actual proposed change, aside from a renaming.
I have made the first paragraph more concise to describe the two changes we will make.
maybe use another word here to avoid repitition of "best" ? Perhaps "first" or "ideal" or "canonical"? Everyone loves to use "canonical" in a sentence right?
Agree that this was kind-of filler.  Have removed.

"now" as in "currently" as in what they're already doing? Or do you mean after this "change"? This paragraph sounds like something is different, but also seems to mean that things are staying the same aside from a more clear place for projects without dedicated teams to get some support.
I have re-written this to more concisely describe what you and Dan have recommended.

yeah, it is after this change. May be we can list the both proposal clearly

1. Project managing their stable core team 
   L 42- 48
2. Renaming 'Extended Maintenance' SIG to 'Stable Maintenance'.
   L 32-40

1st one is actual change here to merge the stable backports faster and 2nd is more of document ion/name change which is trivial as it does not have change anything from what EM SIG is doing.
nit: missing a full stop here

Actually, the original process was not that different from this: if a project's stable core team saw that someone is doing active and good stable backport reviews, then they proposed that person to be a stable core by sending mail to the mailing list usually. Then someone from the stable-maint-core group looked at  the reviews of the person just to double check that the person understand the stable policy and reviews according to it, then was added to the <project>-stable-maint team. 
This kind of mails/pings actually did not happen so often, perhaps because there were not that many new and active stable reviewer around the teams. (I have added 3 reviewers to projects' stable core group this year if I remember well)
Anyway, the goal is to have enough stable core reviewer for the teams who keep their stable branches really *stable* and do maintain them and avoid introducing regressions. If teams feel in this way they will be more flexible and this helps to be more active in stable maintenance then I can accept that.
I'm +1 on the first part, but this second part still seems meaningless to me. I'm not -1 on it but I just don't see the point.

cinder/scheduler/host_manager.py.message: Hi, based on the reply https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/788363/10/cinder/image/cache.py#66 I think we should update this as well, right?

This one really puzzled me (with host:Optional[str] on line 99, this looks like a runtime error waiting to happen).

From what I can tell, host has to be Optional[str] because volume_utils.append_host() returns Optional[str], and append_host() is called to get the value that PoolState's init method passes to super(PoolState).__init__(), which is this __init__ right here.  Since PoolState's __init__ has host:str at line 379, we know that PoolState will always call append_host() with a non-None host value.  So what do you think about removing line 112 and instead doing the assert in PoolState before the call to this __init__ method is made?  Then we can have

  host: str,

at line 99, and we don't need the puzzling line 112 any more.  (I tried it locally, and mypy seems OK with it.)
--warn-redundant-casts is showing that this isn't necessary any more

see comment in BackendState: maybe add

  assert new_host is not None

since we know host is typed as not None at line 379, we should not get None back from append_host(), so I like making the assertion here instead of in the parent class.

cinder/scheduler/weights/capacity.py.message: I guess this is safe to assert because the parent's weigh_objects() will set it and self.minval?
It's needed because self.maxval is Optional but math.isinf() below requires it to be set.
I think your approach makes sense.

> I guess my question was more about how do we know that we're not introducing
> an incorrect statement into the code with this assert?

Basically, we know because math.isinf() at line 79 throws a TypeError already if self.maxval is None.  (Which is why mypy complains.)

One alternative is to do a typing cast, but I think the assert is cleaner.

> The code we're calling at line 75, I think, does make sure that self.minval,
> self.maxval will have values after that call:

Yeah, the problem is, self.maxval is initially set to None and nothing makes the type system aware that this is no longer the case after weigh_objects() is called.  I can see a few potential ways to fix this but they involve actual code changes...

I guess my question was more about how do we know that we're not introducing
an incorrect statement into the code with this assert?

On one hand, I guess it doesn't matter, because if the assert fails, then
the code was going to barf at line 79 anyway.

I think my discomfort here comes from the difference with asserts in python and
java.  In java, you have to specifically enable them at runtime, whereas in
python they are on by default, so you could cause a runtime error with an incorrect assert.

The code we're calling at line 75, I think, does make sure that self.minval,
self.maxval will have values after that call:
https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/336ac06bcf69e4b2a7c782b2544a2079bf23bd6f/cinder/scheduler/base_weight.py#L108-L111

controllerconfig/controllerconfig/upgrad.message: Can use dictionary access. See below.

Don't substitute values into the query string. Values must be passed in as a tuple. See https://www.psycopg.org/docs/usage.html#passing-parameters-to-sql-queries

For example:
>>> query = "INSERT INTO service_parameter (name, value, service, section, personality, resource) values (%s, %s, %s, %s, %s, %s)"
>>> cur.execute(query, (row['name'], row['value'], row['service'], row['section'], row['personality'], row['resource']))
This will work even with null values. Also the db will populate the timestamp and uuid.

use conn.cursor(cursor_factory=RealDictCursor) or conn.cursor(cursor_factory=DictCursor) to get a dictionary back. eg
>>> cur = conn.cursor(cursor_factory=RealDictCursor)
>>> cur.execute("select name, value, personality, resource from service_parameter where service='docker' and section='gcr-registry'")
>>> rows = cur.fetchall()
>>> rows
[{'resource': None, 'name': 'url', 'value': 'gcr.io', 'personality': None}]
nit: specific to handling of ghrc.io registry
could be a new variable, as this shouldnt overwrite the existing row (not that it would here).
in this 'for key' loop this assignment will only be hit once since the 'name' can only match one or the other.

FYI, this has impact to the pod spec of the heat-domain-ks-user and heat-trustee-ks-user jobs, since they already have values defined:

https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm/src/branch/master/heat/values.yaml#L1063-L1065

I don't know enough about those jobs to say whether it's a problem.

It's probably worth documenting (somewhere) the required values.yaml structure, and what needs to go where to make it work.

  .pod.security_context.ks_user.pod - PodSecurityContext/v1 fields
  .pod.security_context.ks_user.container.ks_user - SecurityContext/v1 fields

It might be nice to apply this in a uniform way to all the job manifests in helm-toolkit/template/manifests
Thank you for the feedback , documented with comments.

I looked at those heat jobs this morning. I don't see any impact to the heat-domain-ks-user job specifically because it doesn't use the ks_user job helm-toolkit manifest (the job is defined within the heat chart). However, you're right about the heat-trustee-ks-user job. If both jobs should have the same security context, then I'd suggest changing the heat/values.yaml like this:

  security_context:
    ks_user:
      pod:
        runAsUser: 42424
      container:
        ks_user:
          readOnlyRootFilesystem: true
          allowPrivilegeEscalation: false

...and change the "heat_ks_domain_user" container name to "ks_user" within heat/templates/job-ks-user-domain.yaml, to keep them consistent.  They can then draw from the same security context definition. If they need to be different, then we can create two separate defs in the heat/values.yaml.

And I agree that this HTK function should be documented somewhere. (maybe in the same file, in comments with examples - I see that pattern in some of the snippets and other manifests).

On further review, it looks like there will not be an actual impact (not causing a failure) to the heat-trustee-ks-user job...because the heat_ks_domain_user container name will just get ignored, and there won't be a container level security context applied (only pod level). But someone would need to go back and fix the job (separate PS) so that it has both the pod and container level security contexts.

zuul.d/project.yaml.message: Do not put non voting jobs in the gate. They don't affect gating and will only serve to consume resources there.

we don't have much choice here since job is defined as part of the template  openstack-ansible-deploy-aio_metal-jobs and we merge this patch to solve curcular dependency only. Otherwise dependency would be even more awfull.

You might see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ansible-role-python_venv_build/+/817221 that reverts this one and fixes this.

Yes, this patch is to break a circular dependancy between https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ansible-role-python_venv_build/+/816473 and https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/815633.

The jobs are defined in templates outside this repo so whilst this looks like the addition of a new NV job it's actually making an existing job in the template NV for the purpose of deadlock-breaking.

It's not really great to make the jobs in the template NV for this as it would open us to merging breaking changes in the several dozen repos which use the template during that time.

It would be great to be able to do something like this to knock a specific job out of a template in a job which uses it:

    check:
      skip:
        - openstack-ansible-deploy-aio_metal-centos-7
      jobs:
        - tripleo-ci-centos-7-standalone-os-tempest
    gate:
      skip:
        - openstack-ansible-deploy-aio_metal-centos-7
      jobs:
        - tripleo-ci-centos-7-standalone-os-tempest

This does come up quite a lot for us when we need to deadlock-break, and it's a result of being multi-repo, using of zuul job templates for good DRY-ness in job definitions. Mono-repos would not have this trouble as you could commit all of the fixes in one hit.

doc/notification_samples/common_payloads.message: We need to signal this to the consumers of the versioned notifications somehow. Did we published a release notes deprecating the bandwidth field in previous releases? If yes then what we need here is a reno that tells the user that the field is now removed. If we forgot to send the deprecation message in a past release then we cannot remove it as it will break the clients and they cannot opt into an older version.

Under normal circumstances, I'd be inclined to agree. However, this is field that has never contained any useful information for users on non-XenAPI-based deployments. Unless there are API consumers that strictly enforce the fields they receive via these events (in which case, bad API consumer [1]), then I think we'll be okay.

Would it be sufficient for me to add a release note documenting this removal and improve our contributor docs to make sure we don't miss this again in the future? I'm pretty sure there are other fields that we emit via notifications (particularly where these mirror existing o.vos) which are deprecated and will (hopefully) be eventually removed.

Also, to be clear, if you're aware of consumers in Ericsson that would break with this change (I think you consume versioned notifications?) then obviously say so 😄

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robustness_principle

OK. Lets have a reno (as you provided in ps3). I agree that this is an unusual case where the only source of information for this field was already removed. In general we would need a proper deprecation period for such notification change, but we basically had the deprecation cycle when we deprecated the xenapi driver.

zuul/scheduler.py.message:
Callpath seems to be: 

 scheduler.run()
   scheduler.updateTenantLayout()
     loader.loadTPCs()
       tenant_parser.loadTenantProjects()
         creates new TPC objects on the abide with empty
         parsed_branch_config dicts.
     loader.loadTenant()
       TenantParser.fromYaml()
         tenant.addConfigProject()/tenant.addUntrustedProject()
           tenant._addProject()
             populates tenant.project_configs dict with TPC objects created
             by loader.loadTPCs()
         TenantParser.cacheConfig()
           ParsedConfig from above parsed_branch_config is appended to. 
           Without the loadTPCs the append creates duplicate entries
           on the existing parsed_branch_config entries as they were not
           reset.

Then sometime later we call loader._loadDynamicProjectData() which relies
on the cacheConfig() not containing duplicates.

https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/configloader.py#L2058 is where we append. For belts and suspenders or an alternate fix should we consider having cacheConfig() clear out the parsed_branch_config dicts on the TPC objects before updating them with appends?

I think this should be

    loader.loadTPCs(self.abide, self.unparsed_abide, [tenant_name])
Yep, that matches the tenant reconfig and works.

Let's merge this revert, and keep investigating.

author.name: Julia Kreger

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
It *looks* like the execution ends up trying to reuse the same nbd entry twice, and it *may* be that the first usage of the nbd entry does not actually exit, or is still locked when we try to re-use.

In https://logserver.rdoproject.org/51/817251/1/openstack-check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-ovb-3ctlr_1comp-featureset001/7430611/logs/undercloud/var/log/extra/journal.txt.gz we can see io errors after the first session disconnect, then we try to run again  with nbd0 already apparently being locked "kernel: block nbd0: Device being setup by another task".

For the first execution, we see the filesystem interaction. The second, we appear to just exit upon failure to setup the attachment. It looks like, at least based on the very first commit of the tool that we don't ensure the pv is gone/removed, we're just looking for changes in volume groups. So it may be the LVM layer is still locking the device up.

Realistically, we need to auto-increment and move to nbd1 and also ensure we've done everything possible to cause the device lock to be dropped.

I need to change this.

For Kubernetes, HTTPS is always enabled for both internal and external endpoints.  Kubernetes automatically creates all of its client and server certificates, and signs them with a Kubernetes Root CA.  This includes the server certificate for the external kube-apiserver API endpoint.  By default, the Kubernetes Root CA is automatically generated at install time.

REWORD ?    ( not sure we really need to recommend not using the default )

If desired, you can externally generate a Root CA certificate and key, and configure it as the Kubernetes Root CA during installation.  Upstream Kubernetes (v1.18) only supports a Root CA for the Kubernetes Root CA; NOT an Intermediate CA.  

The public certificate of the Kubernetes Root CA, whether auto-generated or specified, needs to be configured as a trusted CA by external servers connecting to |prod|'s Kubernetes API endpoint (e.g. via a remotely installed kubectl client).

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: fyi, libcgroup is planned to be removed in rhel9. since cnosp got stopped re removed the package from the list via https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-common/+/793976 . it seems it gets still pulled in as a dependency, but that might change. danpb mentioned at that time that we might be able to use systemd-run as a replacement. But haven't checked it

please ignore the dnsmasq processes left behind - that's because we install libvirt on standalone nodes, and have its default network in autostart. On a normal OSP compute there would be no such a problem.
unfortunately, this approach also lefts dnsmasq processes behind with the transient run-rXXX cgroup scopes that used to hold it before libvirt restarted
So those dnsmasq processes lifecycle is managed by neutron via the side car wrappers. I suppose we could leave them around? Or how could we check if neutron would reap it off eventually?

we should not be spawning any dnsmas process in the nova_libvirt container
we are not using libvirts networking capablity for dhcp or dns.

there shoudl be no libvirt networks defiend.
how were they created?
TODO: the same for modular libvirt

if I freeze libvirt (kill -STOP), that changes nothing. Qemu-kvm survives, libvirt container/service gets restarted OK.

if I freeze the conmon that runs theirs libpod-XXX.scope, then both libvirtd and qemu-processes in that scope get wiped.

I don't think we should expect conmon becomes totally unresponsive under "norma" failure scenarios though?
let's hold for a while, need more testing

that failure mode looks like:

qemu-kvm: terminating on signal 15 from pid 1 (<unknown process>)
shutting down, reason=crashed

logged. But I think we can assume that freezing conmon is not a real case. If it happens in real, that means container runtime engine is borked, and we can expect no dataplane available for instances, so there would be no value to keep it up.
